channel.title: Not a Peeker of Nature
channel.description: Recent content on Not a Peeker of Nature

item.title: Basis of 3D genomics
item.description:
Cohesin

Cohesin architecture Nature reviews cancer 2014

  1. Cohesin subunits: SMC1/SMC3, RAD21, and STAG1/2 (SA1/2).
  2. Cohesin cofactors: NIPBL and MAU2, WAPL, PDS5, Sororin, Separase

Conclusions

  1. Loss of Cohesin Is Associated with Stronger Genome Compartmentalization. Cell 2017
  2. Loop Domains Are Rapidly Lost After Degradationof Cohesin. Cell 2017
  3. Links between Superenhancers Are Strengthened after Loss of Cohesin. Cell 2017
  4. Molecular Dynamics Simulations Integrating Extrusion and Compartmentalization Can Recapitulate Hi-C Experimental Results. Cell 2017
  5. Cohesin Loss Results in Strong Down-Regulation of Genes near Superenhancers but Does Not Bring About Widespread Ectopic Activation. Cell 2017
  6. Two Mechanisms that Guide Genome Folding: the first is the cohesin-dependent formation of loop domains; the second mechanism is the cohesin-independent compartmentalization of chromatin intervals with similar histone marks. Cell 2017
  7. Two Classes of Loops: another population of loops that are frequently anchored at superenhancers and do not depend on cohesin. Cell 2017
  8. Loop Domains Spanning NIPBL and Superenhancers Recover More Rapidly. Cell 2017
  9. It is commonly thought that compartment intervals are typically megabases in length and are subdivided into smaller domains in a hierarchical fashion. Here, we demonstrate that compartment intervals can be as short as tens of kilobases and can overlap loop domains in complex ways. For instance, we observe numerous examples of loop domains spanning multiple compartment intervals. Cell 2017
  10. In such cases, we find that loop extrusion, by facilitating contacts between all loci in the loop domain, can enhance the contact frequency of loci that would ordinarily lie in different subcompartments. Thus, the long-range contact pattern seen for each locus is a mixture of the pattern that would ordinarily be seen for loci in the corresponding subcompartment and the pattern seen for other loci in the loop. This mixing disappears upon cohesin depletion. Similarly, deletion of WAPL appears to increase the processivity of the Xcom and thus increases the size of loops (Haarhuis et al., 2017). Consistent with our observations, these larger loops are associated with extensive mixing, which obscures long-range compartment patterns. Cell 2017

item.title: Download the public sequencing data using kingfisher
item.description:
Kingfisher is quite convenient for us to download public sequencing data.

1. Install kingfisher

conda install -c conda-forge -c bioconda kingfisher # pay attention to the channel order

2. Examples of downloading date using kingfisher

kingfisher get -p PRJNA938179 -m aws-http prefetch aws-cp gcp-cp ena-ftp -f fastq --check-md5sums
kingfisher get -p PRJNA938179 -m aws-http prefetch aws-cp gcp-cp ena-ftp -t 16 -f fastq.gz --check-md5sums
kingfisher get -r SRR12044307 -m aws-http prefetch aws-cp gcp-cp ena-ftp -f fastq --check-md5sums
kingfisher get -r SRR12044307 -m aws-http prefetch aws-cp gcp-cp ena-ftp -t 16 -f fastq.gz --check-md5sums

kingfisher get --run-identifiers-list srr_list.txt -m aws-http prefetch aws-cp gcp-cp ena-ftp -t 16 -f fastq.gz --check-md5sums
srr_list.txt <
SRR12044304
SRR12044305
SRR12044306
SRR12044307
SRR12044308
SRR12044309

Appendix 1: aria2c

aria2c -c https://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genomes/all/GCA/020/567/875/GCA_020567875.1_IOCAS_Cari/GCA_020567875.1_IOCAS_Cari_genomic.fna.gz

item.title: Scripts summary
item.description:
To reuse some scripts, here is a summary for myself organized by topics

#3D genomics

1. from .paired.gz to hic

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# ─── User settings ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
data_dir="../data"
sample="HAP-WT"

chromsizes="../annotations/hg38.chrom.sizes"
build="hg38"
juicer_tools="../tools/juicer_tools.2.20.00.jar"

merged_pairs="${data_dir}/${sample}_330M.pairs.gz"
sorted_merged="${merged_pairs%.pairs.gz}.sorted.pairs.gz"
dedup_pairs="${data_dir}/${sample}_330M.nodups.pairs.gz"
sorted_dedup="${dedup_pairs%.pairs.gz}.sorted.pairs.gz"
pre_pairs="${data_dir}/${sample}_330M.forPre.pairs.gz"
hic_file="${data_dir}/${sample}_330M.hic"

# comma‐sep list of resolutions (no spaces!)
res_list="2500000,1000000,500000,250000,100000,50000,25000,10000,5000,1000"

threads=12
# ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

echo "2 sort merged pairs"
pairtools sort --nproc $threads -o "$sorted_merged" "$merged_pairs"

echo "3 global deduplication"
pairtools dedup --nproc-in  $threads --nproc-out $threads --output "$dedup_pairs" "$sorted_merged"

echo "4 sort deduplicated pairs"
pairtools sort --nproc $threads -o "$sorted_dedup" "$dedup_pairs"

echo "5 prepare for juicebox pre:"
gunzip -c "$sorted_dedup" | grep -E '^(## pairs format|^#columns|^[^#])' | gzip -c > "$pre_pairs"

echo "6 building multi-res .hic"
java -Xmx16g -jar "$juicer_tools" pre -t $threads -r "$res_list" "$pre_pairs" "$hic_file" "$build"

#Binformatics

1. change bedgraph to tdf for igv visualization

# conda activate tools_igvtools

genome="hg19"
src_dir="../3_prepare_macs2_peaks_forIGV"

for bg in "$src_dir"/*.bedgraph; do
  base="${bg%.bedgraph}"
  echo ${base}
  tdf=${base}.tdf

  igvtools toTDF ${bg} ${tdf} ${genome}
done

2. draw plot using Python

import pathlib as p
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

import matplotlib
# matplotlib.use('Qt5Agg')
# matplotlib.rcParams['font.family'] = 'Arial'
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.style.use('ggplot')

from scipy.stats import pearsonr, spearmanr, gaussian_kde

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)
pd.set_option('display.width', 500)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    root = p.Path(__file__).absolute().parent

    resolution = 10000
    src_dir = root.parent / f'data_2_cool_{resolution}_targetChroms_normalizeSmallest'
    dest_dir = root.parent / 'result_scatterPlot_of_twoReplicates_allChroms_noLabels_withColorCode'
    dest_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)

    groups = [['ctrl1', 'ctrl2', 'ctrl', '#4D7731']]

    for group in groups:
        rep1 = group[0]
        rep2 = group[1]
        group_name = group[2]
        color_code = group[3]
        print(group_name)
        print(rep1)
        print(rep2)
        c1 = cooler.Cooler(str(src_dir / f'{rep1}_{resolution}_targetChroms_normalizeSmallest.cool'))
        c2 = cooler.Cooler(str(src_dir / f'{rep2}_{resolution}_targetChroms_normalizeSmallest.cool'))

        matrix1_flat_raw = c1.matrix(balance=False)[:].flatten()
        matrix2_flat_raw = c2.matrix(balance=False)[:].flatten()

        matrix1_flat, matrix2_flat = filter_zero_indices(matrix1_flat_raw, matrix2_flat_raw)

        corr_pearson, p_pearson = pearsonr(matrix1_flat, matrix2_flat)

        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(5, 5), dpi=300)
        ax.set_facecolor('white')
        for spine in ax.spines.values():
            spine.set_color('black')
            spine.set_linewidth(1)

        plt.scatter(np.log10(matrix1_flat), np.log10(matrix2_flat), alpha=0.3, s=1.5, c=color_code)
        # plt.scatter(np.log2(matrix1_flat), np.log2(matrix2_flat), alpha=0.3, s=1.5, c='black')
        # sc = ax.scatter(x, y, c=z, s=1.5, alpha=0.3, cmap='inferno')

        ax.set_xticks([1, 2, 3])
        ax.set_xticklabels([10, 100, 1000])
        ax.set_yticks([1, 2, 3])
        ax.set_yticklabels([10, 100, 1000])

        # ax.set_xlabel(f"{group_name}_rep1", fontsize=10)
        # ax.set_ylabel(f"{group_name}_rep2", fontsize=10)
        ax.set_xlabel(f"")
        ax.set_ylabel(f"")

        ax.set_title(f"")

        plt.savefig(dest_dir/f'{group_name}_resolution{resolution}_correlation_twoReps_allChroms_pearsonCorr{corr_pearson:.2f}_noLabels_withColorCode.png', dpi=300)

item.title: Terminology summary
item.description:
To memorize some frequently used terminologies and their pronunciations, here is a summary organized by topics

#Cell biology

1. Cell cycle and chromosomes

mitosis /maɪˈtoʊsɪs/ 有丝分裂
meiosis /maɪˈoʊsɪs/ 减数分裂
amitosis /ˌæmaɪˈtoʊsɪs/ 无丝分裂 polyploid /ˈpɒlɪplɔɪd/ 多倍体
diploid /ˈdɪplɔɪd/ 二倍体
autopolyploid /ˌɔːtoʊˈpɒlɪplɔɪd/ allopolyploid /ˌæloʊˈpɒlɪplɔɪd/ heterozygosity /ˌhetərəʊzaɪˈɡɒsəti/ 杂合度；杂合性
homozygosity /ˌhəʊməʊzaɪˈɡɒsəti/ 纯合性；纯合度
karyotype /ˈkær.i.oʊ.taɪp/ 核型

#Genomics

1. Comparative genomics and evolution

synteny /ˈsɪntəni/ 共线性
lineages /ˈlɪniɪdʒɪz/ 常指从共同祖先演化而来的连续种群或物种分支，比如“进化谱系”。
synonymous substitutions /sɪˈnɒnɪməs ˌsʌbstɪˈtjuːʃənz/ 同义替换 或 同义突变
paralogous genes /ˌpærəˈlɒɡəs dʒiːnz/ 旁系同源基因，指同一物种基因组中，由基因复制（gene duplication）事件产生的同源基因，这些基因在功能上可能相似，也可能已经分化。
orthologous genes /ˈɔːrθəlɒɡəs dʒiːnz/ 直系同源基因，源自基因复制（duplication）事件，出现在同一物种基因组内。
progenitors /prəˈdʒɛnɪtəz/ 祖先

item.title: Build personal website with Gokarna as the theme
item.description:
Build personal website and host it on github so that both I and other readers can easily access the content

1. Using Hugo with Gokarna as the theme

a. Follow the Gokarna tutorial to install GO, HUGO, and git

b. Create the project and install Gokarna theme

hugo new site my-website
cd my-website
git init
git submodule add https://github.com/gokarna-theme/gokarna-hugo.git themes/gokarna

c. Fill in configuaration file

>>cat hugo.toml 
baseURL = "https://astudentfromsustech.github.io/"
title = "Not a Peeker of Nature"
theme = "gokarna"
languageCode = "en"
defaultContentLanguage = "en"
enableEmoji = true
enableRobotsTXT = true

# Choose one of emacs, trac or perldoc
pygmentsStyle = "monokai"

[params]
footer = "Pengfei Yin"
description = "Genomics | Computational Biology | Physics"
avatarURL = "/images/avatar.jpg"
AvatarAltText = "avatar"
avatarSize = "size-l"
showPostsOnHomePage = "recent"
ShowBackToTopButton = true # true or false for "back to top" button on posts
customHeadHTML = """
    <!-- KaTeX -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/katex@0.16.0/dist/katex.min.css" integrity="sha384-Xi8rHCmBmhbuyyhbI88391ZKP2dmfnOl4rT9ZfRI7mLTdk1wblIUnrIq35nqwEvC" crossorigin="anonymous">
    <script defer src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/katex@0.16.0/dist/katex.min.js" integrity="sha384-X/XCfMm41VSsqRNQgDerQczD69XqmjOOOwYQvr/uuC+j4OPoNhVgjdGFwhvN02Ja" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>
    <script defer src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/katex@0.16.0/dist/contrib/auto-render.min.js" integrity="sha384-+XBljXPPiv+OzfbB3cVmLHf4hdUFHlWNZN5spNQ7rmHTXpd7WvJum6fIACpNNfIR" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>
    <script>
    document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function() {
        renderMathInElement(document.body, {
        // customised options
        // • auto-render specific keys, e.g.:
        delimiters: [
            {left: '$$', right: '$$', display: true},
            {left: '$', right: '$', display: false},
        ],
        // • rendering keys, e.g.:
        throwOnError : false
        });
    });
    </script>
"""
socialIcons = [
    {name = "github", url = "https://github.com/astudentfromsustech"},
    {name = "twitter", url = "https://twitter.com/Pengfei_Yin_"},
    {name = "email", url = "12133074@mail.sustech.edu.cn"}
]
metaKeywords = ["blog", "gokarna", "hugo"]

[menu]
[[menu.main]]
    name = "Home"
    pre = "<span data-feather='home'></span>"
#   url = "https://astudentfromsustech.github.io/"
    url = "/"
    weight = 1

[[menu.main]]
    name = "Posts"
    pre = "<span data-feather='book'></span>"
#   url = "https://astudentfromsustech.github.io/posts/"
    url = "/posts/"
    weight = 3

[[menu.main]]
    name = "Projects"
    pre = "<span data-feather='code'></span>"
#   url = "https://astudentfromsustech.github.io/projects/"
    url = "/projects/"
    weight = 4

[[menu.main]]
    name = "Tags"
    pre = "<span data-feather='tag'></span>"
#   url = "https://astudentfromsustech.github.io/tags/"
    url = "/tags/"
    weight = 5

[[menu.main]]
    name = "Abouts"
    pre = "<span data-feather='users'></span>"
#   url = "https://astudentfromsustech.github.io/about/"
    url = "/abouts/"
    weight = 2

[markup]
[markup.tableOfContents]
    startLevel = 1
    endLevel = 4
    ordered = false

d. Launching the Website Locally

hugo server

2. Host the public diretory on github using a seperate branch

a. Generate the SSH Key

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com

b. Add your SSH key to the agent

# for Ed25519 key, if you’re using RSA, use the corresponding file (e.g., ~/.ssh/id_rsa). 
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

c. Add your public key to GitHub

# copy the content of ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub or ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub # or  pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
# paste the public key to the “Key” field (click the New SSH key in GitHub SSH Settings)

d. Keep public in a separate branch (Another choice is to directly push the public directory)

# Remove the .git Folder in public
cd /Users/fayevalentine/Desktop/tools/tools_2_hugo/hugo/ypf_website/public
rm -rf .git 

# Clone Your GitHub Pages Repository Locally
cd ~/repos
git clone git@github.com:astudentfromsustech/astudentfromsustech.github.io.git  

# Copy the generated public directory to the repository root
cd astudentfromsustech.github.io
cp -R /Users/fayevalentine/Desktop/tools/tools_2_hugo/hugo/ypf_website/public/* .  

# Commit and Push the Files
git add .
git commit -m "Publish Hugo site: update GitHub Pages site"
git push -u origin master

item.title: About me (all text)
item.description:
About me

My name is Pengfei Yin (殷鹏飞). I completed my BSc at the Ocean University of China, where I was deeply attracted to how mechanisms underlying molecular biology are discovered. Since then, I have been systematically enhancing my ability to decipher biological mechanisms. In addition to experiments, numerous scientific studies demonstrate that Physics (Francis Crick) and computational analysis can also help us understand the biological phenomena. Thus, I have developed a background in molecular biology, complemented by training in mathematical modeling and core courses for Physics students (including the 3 volumes of the Feynman Lectures on Physics).

item.title: Thesis project
item.description:
Thesis project: Dynamic 3D chromatin architecture of active and inactive regions and gene regulation of Drosophila under heat stress

if load the figures slowly, please click the link to read its pdf format

Fig.1 and Fig.S1 (Experiment design and good data quality)

  1. The experiment design (Fig.1A)
  2. High reproducibility (Fig.1B,C,D and Fig.S1A,C)
  3. Typical heat shock related genes are up-regulated (Fig.1D and Fig.S1B)

Fig1

FigS1

Fig.2 and Fig.S2 (The most interesting features blocks in H3K27me3 and stripes in H3K27ac are found through loop analysis)

  1. Loop analysis indicates there is something interesting(Fig.2A,B and Fig.S2A,B).
  2. Find the most interesting features: blocks in H3K27me3 and stripes in H3K27ac.And A/B compartments highly align with H3K27ac-dominant and H3K27me3-dominant regions respectively, which also correspond the positions of stripes and blocks. Besides, the stripes and blocks become more obvious, and the pattern of RNAP2 is more similar to that of H3K27ac than H3K27me3 (Fig.2C,D,E and Fig.S2C,D,F)
  3. A/B compartments called using log2(H3K27ac_ChIA-PE/H3K27me3_ChIA-PE) align with those identified using PCA method overall, but in some positions, A/B compartments called using log2(H3K27ac_ChIA-PE/H3K27me3_ChIA-PE) align better with the stripes and blocks. (Fig.S2C,D,E)

Fig2

item.title: Commands summary
item.description:
#commonly used

juR96QR6

#Linux

  1. truncate -s 0 file # empty a file with file name kept to save disk memory

#HPC-SCC

  1. frequently used commands
sbatch submit.sbatch # submit a sbatch job
squeue -u $USER # check the submitted jobs 
scancel <JOBID> #  kill a job
ps -u $USER # show your processes
pkill -u $USER # kill all your processes on this node (be careful!)
  1. download data 0_get_data.sh
kingfisher get --run-identifiers-list srr_list.txt -m aws-http prefetch aws-cp gcp-cp ena-ftp -t 16 -f fastq.gz --check-md5sums

srr_list

item.title: Pipelines summary
item.description:
#Routine pipelines with dockers/singularity images

1.RNA-seq: https://rumball.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
2.ChIP-seq: https://churros.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
3.Hi-C: https://custardpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
4.Single-cell: https://github.com/rnakato/ShortCake

Tip 1: change the sif image into sandbox so that we can edit the sif image

singularity build --sandbox /path/to/rumball_sandbox /path/to/rumball.0.7.4.sif
singularity shell --writable /path/to/rumball_sandbox # now we enter the sif image and we can do some modifications as we need
singularity exec /path/to/rumball_sandbox /opt/RumBall/rsem_merge_GeneOnly.sh "$HaCaT_WT $HaCaT_C3KO" Matrix_deseq2/HaCaT_WT_C3KO $Ddir # rsem_merge_GeneOnly.sh is the modified script inside the sif image

#Single-cell genomics (very comprehensive)

https://www.sc-best-practices.org/preamble.html

item.title: Tools summary
item.description:
#1 Build personal website and host it on github

#2 Download public sequencing data
